sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Further information on the distribution of
Aporia procris Leech, 1890
is provided. The population of
A. procris
from the upper Dadu River, W. Sichuan , previously recognized as
ssp. yaozhui Huang, 2021
, is treated as a new subspecies, viz., A. p. huangsiyaoi ssp. nov. , based upon evidence from external features, with its genital and molecular characters given.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
As stated by
,
Aporia procris Leech, 1890
is a Palaearctic pierid butterfly with considerable variation in wing pattern, leading to ambiguity in defining its geographical populations (
). Based on previous literature,
compiled a taxonomic checklist including the subspecies of
A. procris
, an arrangement that has been continued not only in subsequent works by themselves (
;
) but also accepted by other authors such as
.

Recently,
brought the aforementioned treatment on
A. procris
up to date based on examinations of a great number of specimens from diverse localities. Huang’s work involved correcting some erroneous classifications and describing two additional subspecies. One of the newly erected subspecies, yaozhui
(TL: S. Qamdo, Xizang ), was previously illustrated both in
and
;
) but regarded as another little-known subspecies,
ssp. nyanchuensis Yoshino, 1998
. In terms of distribution,
ssp. yaozhui
has a vast range, extending from its type locality, N.E. Xizang , to Jinchuan, W. Sichuan . Nevertheless, upon examining a series of
A. procris
collected from Jinchuan and Barkam, along with those listed in
, it became evident that the individuals from the upper Dadu River exhibit distinct external features that set them apart from
ssp. yaozhui
and other recognized subspecies.

Hence, the present study aims to distinguish
A. procris
found in the upper Dadu River, which is far from the type locality of
ssp. yaozhui
, and assign a new name to this focal population.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: Morphological examination

Eight males of

27. V .2023

A. p. procris
from adjacent areas were also examined for comparison: several specimens from areas between Jiangda (Gyamda) and Jinchuan (unpublished data, C.J. Chang pers. comm.); 1 ♂ , Mt. Siguniang, Xiaojin, Aba, Sichuan , 7.VII.2020 , H.Z. Li leg. ( CHZL ; SGN1; OR146970); 3 ♂♂ , Yala Snow Mountain, Ganzi, Sichuan , 1500m , 15–20.VIII.2022 , Ding-Le-Heng Lv leg. sec.title: Molecular analyses
sec.p: The Cytb gene is chosen for genetic distances and phylogenetic analyses. DNA extractions were conducted by Beijing Tsingke Biotech Co., Ltd. ( Beijing , China ). The PCR reaction was applied in a 30 µL system by using 15 µL of Mix (I-5TM 2×High Fidelity Master Mix, Beijing Tsingke Biotech Co., Ltd.), 1 µL of gDNA, 12 µL of dH 2 O, and 1 µL of each of forward and reverse primers (the general primers CB1 and CB2 utilized). The thermal profile of PCR consisted of a pre-denaturation at 98°C for 3 min, 37 cycles of denaturation at 98°C for 10 s, annealing at 53°C for 15 s, and elongation at 72°C for 15 s, then a final elongation at 72°C for 5 min.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The
A. procris
inhabiting the upper Dadu River displays distinct morphological characters that would allow its differentiation from all other named subspecies. In particular, it can be distinguished from the nominotypical subspecies by the less pronounced streaks and less dusted veins on the hindwing underside ( Figs. 1–2 ). Meanwhile, this newly found population can be easily separated from
ssp. yaozhui
by the uniformly distributed coloration on the hindwing underside, whereas this becomes paler in the central areas of spaces in the latter subspecies (
; Hang 2021) ( Figs. 1–2 ). Additionally, the localities inhabited by the Jinchuan and Barkam populations appear to be situated within the extensive range of the nominate subspecies, thereby impeding the establishment of Tibetan
ssp. yaozhui
in Sichuan ( Fig. 5 ). Therefore, considering these superficial distinctions and zoogeographical perspectives, the Jinchuan and Barkam representatives, once recognized as
ssp. yaozhui
, deserve to be assigned to a new taxon.

However, given the embedded distribution pattern of
A. procris
from Jinchuan and Barkam, in conjunction with the notable subspecific diversity of this species in the Sino-Himalayan regions, it is possible that there could be multiple species within
A. procris
rather than a single species. However, there is no reliable geographical variation in male genitalia among specimens of all subspecies (
; S. J. Hu et al. 2021;
) ( Fig. 4 ), suggesting they are conspecific, a view also shared by
. Moreover, the low molecular divergence between the population from Jinchuan and the nominotypical subspecies also confirms their conspecificity, with only a singleton difference in Cytb (av. 0.25% in K2P) ( Fig. 6 ).

In conclusion, treating this potential taxon as a subspecies is preferable to a distinct species, supported by the homology of genital structures and by the evidence from molecular phylogeny. Hence, a new subspecies-level taxon is proposed and described below.

Diagnosis. This new subspecies can be distinguished from all six subspecies of
A. procris
by the combination of the following characteristics (
):

1. Sagittate markings on the hindwing underside are less developed, but not obscure as in
ssp. nyanchuensis
, whereas the markings are more elongated and closer to the termen in other subspecies.

2. Veins on the hindwing underside are less dusted, while the veins are heavily covered with black scales in other subspecies except
ssp. yaozhui
.

3. Background on the hindwing underside is unicolorous, similar to that of
ssp. procris
and
ssp. sinensis
, whereas the coloration is more or less not uniformly distributed in other subspecies.
Distribution. Currently only known from Jinchuan and Barkam (W. Sichuan , China ).
Etymology. The subspecific name is dedicated to Mr. Si-Yao Huang, who frequently offers the author taxonomic help.

Ecology. In Jinchuan, this butterfly can be encountered in puddling posture around sandy moist spots on the banks of forest streams at ca. 2400m , mixed with
A. goutellei (Oberthür, 1886)
,
A. bernardi Koiwaya, 1989
,
Pieris venata Leech, 1891
,
P. davidis Oberthür, 1876
, and
P. stotzneri (Draeseke, 1924)
. It is noteworthy that this butterfly disappears at higher elevations (alt.> 2900m ) where
P. dubernardi Oberthür, 1884
is found, sympatric with other pierid species mentioned above.

Remarks. Both the photos provided by Ding (2017) and its locality from Shaanxi verify that the gene sequences of an “
A. procris
” enumerated in Ding & Zhang (2017) , which bears a significant genetic distance from other
A. procris
, av. 7.18%, is definitely a misidentification of
A. tsinglingica (Verity, [1911])
(
). This issue probably comes from the first version of a well-known monograph edited by Chou (1994) , where a pair of
A. tsinglingica
was misidentified as
A. procris
. Although Chou noted his misidentification and corrected it in his later works ( Chou 1998 ; 2000 ), some authors, such as Shang & Tian (2017) , still followed the misleading opinion in Chou’s early work.
